questions.explanation: Hydrological natural disasters cause the most deaths.The Disaster Information Management System of Deslnventar classifies natural disasters into fivemajor categories. questions.question: Which of the following is the most common disease after a disaster?
questions.explanation: Gastroenteritis is the most commonly reported disease after a disaster.It occurs due to contamination of water supply, damage to the sewerage system, overcrowdingand poor sanitation. Therefore, supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta arethe most practical and effective strategies of disease prevention in the post-disaster period.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period?
questions.explanation: Leishmaniasis is not commonly seen in the post-disaster period.Diseases that are commonly seen in the post-disaster phase are:•••Gastroenteritis (most common)• Acute respiratory infections⚫ Leptospirosis• Rickettsiosis• Rabies•Equine encephalitis

questions.question: A district in Andhra Pradesh reported severe drought. Which of the following vitamindeficiencies would you expect to see in this population?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A deficiency is the most common deficiency in areas of famines and droughts. It leadsto xerophthalmia and blindness.686

questions.question: Following a drought in Bihar, the government launched an immediate mass vaccinationprogram. Which of the following vaccines is recommended in such cases?
questions.explanation: Measles vaccination is recommended for infants and children, immediately following a disaster.This should be given along with vitamin A supplementation as measles can exacerbate vitamin Adeficiency.The vaccination of infants and children against measles is one of the most important public healthresponse measures during a humanitarian crisis when less than 90% of the children or anunknown percentage have already been vaccinated against measles.Measles and polio vaccines are recommended immediately after an emergency.Option A: Cholera vaccine is not recommended.Option B: Hepatitis A vaccine is recommended at the outset of an outbreak.Option C: Tetanus vaccine is recommended in the early stages and post-emergency stage.

questions.question: Immediately following a disaster, mass vaccination of which of the following vaccines doesthe WHO recommend?
questions.explanation: The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera, and rabies vaccines for mass vaccination after adisaster. However, high-risk populations are recommended to take the cholera vaccine. The rabiesvaccine is given only for post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.question: You are a field doctor at the site of an earthquake. You assist in rapidly classifying the injuredon the basis of the likelihood of their survival and need for intervention. What is thiscalled?
questions.explanation: The process of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury andlikelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention is called triage. It is carried out at the siteof disaster.Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place oforigin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.explanation: In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.An internationally accepted four-color coded system, with red having the highest priority is usedcommonly here.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct about reverse triage?

options.A: Classifying the victims based on the severity of their injuries and their survival with treatment680
options.B: Highest preference is given to severely injured patients
options.C: More injured victims are given the lowest preference
options.D: Color coding is done with red as the highest priority.

questions.explanation: 687Reverse triage is a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that areinjured more.This is used in wars and military settings, where soldiers may need to return to the field of battlesoon after treatment. It is also done when there is a scarcity of medical resources after a disaster.The surge capacity of hospitals is increased to accommodate for the natural disaster, bydischarging non-emergent existing patients. This enables hospitals to allow for an acute increasein incoming patients.

questions.question: Triage is done during disaster management to ensure treatment of casualties is doneproperly. What is true about triage done at the disaster site?

options.B: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
options.C: Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
options.D: Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.explanation: Moribund patients receive the lowest priority.This is because despite paying quite a lot of attention, the benefit is still questionable.

questions.question: What is the level of residual chlorine to be maintained in the water bodies after a disaster?
questions.explanation: The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is 0.7-0.9 mg/L.Chlorine is a disinfectant that is added to water bodies. In normal conditions, water should havefree residual chlorine (FRC) of 0.2 - 0.5 mg/L. However, during a disaster, there is an increasedrisk of fecal contamination of water sources from the sewage systems. Therefore, it is necessary toincrease FRC to 0.7 0.9 mg/L.

questions.question: Which of the following gas was responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy?
questions.explanation: The gas responsible for the Bhopal Gas Tragedy, which occurred on 3rd December 1984 at theUnion Carbide Pesticide Plant, was methyl isocyanate.

questions.question: Which of the following emission occurred in Chernobyl explosion accident of 1986?
questions.explanation: Chernobyl nuclear explosion occurred on 26th April, 1986, in the Soviet Union. It caused therelease of Iodine-1131, Cesium-Cs134, Cs137, and Strontium-Sr90, and other isotopes into theatmosphere.

questions.question: What is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India?

options.B: Ministry of Environment, Forest, and Climate change

questions.explanation: The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management at the Centre exceptfor dealing with droughts which are under the purview of the Ministry of Agriculture.688Other parts of the Indian government involved in disaster management are the EmergencyMedical Relief Wing under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.The Indian Meteorological Department plays a role in mitigation of disaster and its preparedness.

questions.question: Which of the following is a nodal centre in case of disaster management?
questions.explanation: The district disaster management authority is the nodal center for disaster management.It is chaired by either, the District Collector, District Magistrate or the Deputy Commissioner. TheChief Medical Officer of the district is a part of this authority.

questions.question: The NIDM is involved in the mitigation and management of disasters in India. Who is thepresident of this institution?
questions.explanation: The National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM) is under the Ministry of Home Affairs ofIndia. Its president is the Union Home Minister.National Institute of Disaster Management is a premier institute for training and capacitydevelopment programs for managing natural disasters in India, on a national as well as regionalbasis.National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) is an apex body of the Government of India,with a mandate to lay down policies for disaster management. It is chaired by the Prime Ministerof India.
